First demo
Observations (m): %d, variables (n): %d, random matrix of regressors (A): randn(m,n)
Vector of outputs b = %s
Given the previous vector b, it is evident that regressors sorted by
decreasing order of importance are: [5 3 1 2 4] (look to the coefficients used in b)
Second demo
In this second demo, we change the vector b as follows\nb = %s
In this case, it is evident that all regressors have the same importance.
This will be highlighted by the chart on Error Reduction Ratio as a function of the
number of regressors: it will be practically a straight line.
Furthermore, the order of the most important is random!
Error Reduction Ratio (ERR)
Index of the most important regression variables
Matrix A has %d rows (observations) and %d columns (regression variables)
OLS error: The number of observations shall be strictly greater than the number of variables
The threshold parameter shall be provided when r is empty
If r is provided, the threshold parameter has to be empty
The number of regressors cannot be greater than the number of columns of A
The number of regressors cannot be less or equal to zero
The number of regressors r must be a positive integer in the range (1,size(A,2))
(Classical) Least Square (LS) solution
Orthogonal Least Square (OLS) solution using all regressors:
Order of relevance between regressors (sorted from the more important to the less one):

Now we check wether the solution provided by OLS for a given r is the same as
the solution given by LS (Classical Least Squares), when considering the best r regressors
returned by OLS (if the value is significantly low then the test is passed): %g\n
Now we test the orthogonality of the transformed regressors in the orthogonal space
